title: All Persona Games, Ranked From Worst to Best
author: Jesse Lab
categories: Persona Q: Shadow of the Labyrinth
excerpt: Here is a list of all the Persona games ranked from worst to best, from titles like Dancing in Starlight all the way to 5 Royal and 4 Golden!

And of course, like with any major franchise, there are spinoffs galore, including films, anime, audio dramas, and, yes, plenty more video games. Many consider the Persona series to be the pinnacle of modern JRPGs, so we’re going to rank them from worst to best. While most games in the series are standalone, we will make note of entries that have remakes, sometimes with more content than their base version, so we will rank the version that we consider to be the definitive version of each mainline entry, with one major exception, while noting specific release dates for each significant revision. Seriously, putting your characters in wacky costumes means nothing if you’re focused on the music notes emanating away from them. There are only a few exceedingly small strengths that Dancing in Moonlight has. First, the game opted to create new HD character models for the Persona 3 cast, which look gorgeous and make me wish that we actually got a full remake of Persona 3. P4G is a great overall package, but because it’s a mystery, the story loses some of its luster on a second playthrough, and it’s easily the most dated of the three, given that the other two have had enhanced remakes. And then there’s P5R, which boats an absurd amount of content and has some of the best style and atmosphere of any JRPG, but it loses steam towards the end and becomes a slog to get through. It’s ultimately up to you which game to start with, but there’s absolutely nothing wrong with starting off with the gold standard in our eyes, Persona 4 Golden. 1) Persona 4 Golden

There’s something simply magical about experiencing Persona 4 Golden that no other game in the series can match. The tone of the game is lighthearted and optimistic, allowing you to become acquainted with the best cast in the series and take part in several small events that only serve to endear you to them. While the gameplay isn’t as advanced as in Persona 5, the core is still solid, and Persona 4 offers probably the fairest challenge in the series with a handful of bosses that will punish you if you don’t play by their rules.

And while Persona 5 sags a bit in the middle and Persona 3 takes a while to really get going, Persona 4 hits the ground running with a compelling murder mystery that keeps you engaged the entire time, in no small part thanks to the reinvention of Shadows and using them as an allegorical reflection of the main cast. A lot of what made Persona 5’s plot work is directly drawn from here, and this game does it better. It’s genius, incredibly progressive for its time, and tells a meaningful and great story without overstaying its welcome. Overall, Persona 4 Golden is an easy pick for the best game in the franchise.

What’s the Best Persona Game for Newcomers?

So with that over and done with, now the question comes to if you could start with any Persona game, which one should it be?

While Persona 4 Golden may be the best Persona game, in our opinion, depending on what you’re looking for in a video game, you may be interested in other entries. Honestly, 3, 4, and 5 are all great jumping on points for different reasons.

P3R may not have the best start and takes a while to get going, and the central dungeon can become incredibly repetitive, but the cast is likable, and it arguably has the best ending in the series (just don’t play Episode Aigis). P4G is a great overall package, but because it’s a mystery, the story loses some of its luster on a second playthrough, and it’s easily the most dated of the three, given that the other two have had enhanced remakes. And then there’s P5R, which boats an absurd amount of content and has some of the best style and atmosphere of any JRPG, but it loses steam towards the end and becomes a slog to get through. It’s ultimately up to you which game to start with, but there’s absolutely nothing wrong with starting off with the gold standard in our eyes, Persona 4 Golden.

And that is all the Persona games, ranked from worst to best.
